titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Rutherfurd Collection
1642-1845
MS 531
titlestmt.author: Erin Weinman

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-04-12 14:17:28 -0400.

physdesc.extent: 11 document boxes on 3 microfilm reels and 21 volumes.

did.abstract: The Rutherfurd Collection contains material created by or pertaining to members of the Rutherfurd and Alexander families of New York City and New Jersey. The collection is primarily composed of official and private correspondence pertaining to business affairs, political affairs, land disputes, and military activities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Rutherfurd Collection is composed of correspondence, maps, printed items, and miscellaneous manuscripts, circa 1710-1803, that pertain to the Alexander and Rutherfurd families. The papers of James Alexander (b.1726-d.1783), his son William Alexander (b.1726-d.1783), Walter Rutherfurd (b.1723-d.1804), and the latter's son, John Rutherfurd (b.1760-d.1840) are heavily represented in this collection.

The material pertaining to James Alexander include his correspondence with important colonial figures such as Robert Hunter, Cadwallader Colden, John Montgomerie, Lewis Morris (b.1671-d.1746), Lewis Morris, Jr., William Burnet, William Smith (b.1697-d.1769), Vincent Mathews, Philip Livingston, Peter Collinson, Robert Hunter Morris, and others. The letters concern such matters as Alexander's handling of ex-Governor Hunter's private affairs in New York, his own law practice, land purchases, sales, and disputes in New York and New Jersey, Lewis Morris's mission to London, charges against governors and other officials of New York, activities of agents in London, negotiations in England about New Jersey affairs, salary disputes, the defense of John Peter Zenger, elections in New York, the sale of Indian lands at Ticonderoga, the partition line between the Eastern and Western Divisions of New Jersey, the New Jersey land riots of the late 1740s and 1750s, and other affairs in New York.

The William Alexander papers relate mostly to his activities and interests as a contractor of supplies for the army during the French and Indian War, including correspondence with Peter Van Brugh Livingston, General William Shirley, Major John Rutherfurd, John Brainerd, Elihu Spencer, and others. The letters also relate to such matters as the defense of Oswego, construction of vessels there, the raising and transportation of troops and supplies, the Crown Point expedition in 1759, and the siege of Detroit in 1763.

The Walter Rutherfurd correspondence includes 12 letters from his nephew, John Rutherfurd, who wrote about his experiences as a subaltern in Col. Henry Bouquet's expedition to Fort Pitt during Pontiac's War, and letters from his brother, Baron Robert Rutherfurd (b.1719-d.1794), written during 1756-1794, from Leghorn, Italy, where he engaged in the mercantile business until 1777, then from London, his estate near Kelso and Edinburgh, in Scotland. He writes about life in Italy, family matters, the 1764 famine in Italy, European and American affairs, and commerce between Leghorn and America, particularly New York, where Walter was engaged in trade. Included in this part of the collection are letters from Walter to his son, John, during 1783-1803, written from New York City and the family estate, Edgerston, in New Jersey. He writes of their business affairs, particularly their New Jersey lands, friends and relations, family matters, and gives the current news about politics, prominent persons, and local events.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Rutherfurd Collection is organized into three series:

list.item: Series III: Genealogy, Printed Material, and Account Book, 1650-1939

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: The collection should be cited as the Rutherfurd Collection, MS 531, New-York Historical Society.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to 20 exposures of stable, unbound material per day.
Application to use images from this collection for publication should be made in writing to: Department of Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024-5194, rightsandrepro@nyhistory.org. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282.

Copyrights and other proprietary rights may subsist in individuals and entities other than the New-York Historical Society, in which case the patron is responsible for securing permission from those parties. For fuller information about rights and reproductions from N-YHS visit: https://www.nyhistory.org/about/rights-reproductions

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Open to qualified researchers. The collection has been microfilmed and will be brought to the researcher in that format. Researchers on site may print out unlimited copies from microfilm reader-printer machines at per-exposure rates. See guidelines in Reading room for details.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: James Alexander (1691-1756) was a prominant New York statesman and lawyer. Born in Scotland on May 27, 1691, he arrived in New York in 1715 after being appointed to the position of General Surveyer of New Jersey. He married Mary Spratt Provoost (1693-1760), the widow of Samuel Provoost (d. 1719) and a merchant, on June 5, 1721. During this time, Alexander was admitted to the provincial bar and served consecutively as Attorney General in New York and New Jersey. In his later years, he continued to be active in New York politics, raised funds for Kings College, and was a founding member of the American Philosphical Society in Philadelphia. He died in New York on April 2, 1756.

William Alexander was born to James Alexander and Mary Spratt Alexander in 1726. Taking the family title of Lord Stirling, William Alexander would go on to have a successful military career. During the French and Indian War, he was responsible for supplying General Shirley's 1755 expedition to Oswego, NY. William Alexander married Sarah Livingston in 1748 and was active in his family's businesses. In the years leading up to the American Revolution, Alexander began to oppose and rebel against the Crown. His military experience earned him a commission as Brigadier General in 1776. He remained a key figure for the duration of the war and died on January 15, 1783.

Walter Rutherfurd (1723-1804) was born in Scotland to Sir John and Elizabeth Rutherfurd. He arrived in America in 1758 to serve in the French and Indian War with the Royal American Regiment. As a reward for his service, he was granted land in the Province of New Jersey. His marriage to Catherine Alexander, daughter of James Alexander, brought him property holdings in New York. With the help of his connections back in Europe, he went into importng goods and became one of the wealthiest citizens in New York. He helped found the New York Hospital (today New York-Presbyterian Hospital), the Tontine Coffee House, and the St. Andrew's Society of the State of New York. He died in New York City on January 10, 1804.

John Rutherfurd (1760-1840) was born in New York City to Walter and Catherine Alexander Rutherfurd. Like his father and maternal grandfather, he went into politics and worked as a land surveyer. Rutherfurd served a role in the New Jersey General Assembly before representing the state as a Federalist in the United States Senate from 1791 to 1798. He eventually settled with his family in New Jersey. His property was incorporated into the town of Rutherford, NJ, which is named in his honor. John Rutherfurd died in New Jersey on February 23, 1840.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains letters of correspondence from various members of the Alexander and Rutherfurd families. Primary correspondents include James Alexander, William Alexander, Walter Rutherfurd, John Rutherfurd, Cadwallader Colden, Lewis Morris, and Peter Collinson.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The contents of Series I were originally bound into six volumes and are arranged by their original order by volume. The page number is indicated in brackets. The volumes of Subseries I.A include a table of contents and transcriptions that correspond to the six volumes and have been kept in their original order.
Series I is available on microfilm.

did.unittitle: Subseries I.A: Table of Contents and Transcriptions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two sets of Contents for Albums 1-4 of the Rutherfurd Collection. There is an entry for each page in the albums describing the document / correspondence, etc. on that page. Some of the entries are lengthy and may include transcription from the document; others are brief. The two sets are almost identical although one has, at the end of its fourth volume, a Table of Contents for albums 1-4 that consists of a one-line entry for each page. Volumes 9-12 include word-for-word transcriptions of portions of the Rutherfurd Collection correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Much of the material in Subseries I.C pertains to the 1734 trial of John Peter Zenger (1697-1746), a German-born printer and journalist, on the charge of libel. Although he was ultimately acquited, the trial would be one of the earliest cases concerning freedom of the press.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The contents of Series II were originally bound into 2 scrapbooks, which included a large and a small scrapbook. The items were unbound during conservation, but maintain their original order. The page number of each item is indicated in brackets.
Series II is available on microfilm.

did.unittitle: [146A] Queries from the Board of Trade
Series III: Genealogy, Printed Material, and Account Book

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of genealogical material, volumes owned by various members of the family, and an account book. The final volume of the sub-series contains blank pages.

did.unittitle: Family Records and Events by Livingston Rutherfurd. New York: the De Vinne Press
Descendants of Lewis Morris of Morrisania, compiled by Elizabeth Morris Lefferts
The Flowers of Shakespeare, given to Miss L.M. Rutherfurd

"History Naturall and Experimentall of Life and Death or Of the Prolongation of Life", "Sylva Sylvarum: A Natural History in Ten Centuries"; and "New Atlantis, A Work Unfinished", bound together, 1650, 1651 by Francis Bacon
John Peter Zenger His Press, His Trial and a Bibliography of Zenger Imprints by Livingston Rutherfurd
The Constitution and Nominations of the Subscribers to the Tontine Coffee-House. New York: Printed in the Year 1796

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Volume containing blank pages and labeled "Volume VII"
